review_title: It all comes down to poor Management on every level
pros: There are a lot of really good employees. For the most part, staff are hard working and really care about giving excellent patient care.
cons:
Very poor management on all levels - From upper management to mid-level to departmental management teams.  High Mgmt turnover within departments. You have people in decision making roles who have no idea what is really going on. There is a huge disconnect between management and staff. Management spends way too much time behind closed doors or in meetings.  These people are professional meetings attendees. They do little more than that. Then you have the "Managers" who do nothing but sit in an office all day and get paid. Their own staff have no idea what their purpose is.  This used to be a great hospital at one time, but poor management and leadership has run it into the ground. Don't even get me started on the pay and horrible benefits! The insurance has a $4500 deductible!! Someone in HR actually thought this was a good idea??!! The hard working staff in the trenches doing all the work everyday get no
Respect or appreciation, but we all stick it out hoping that someday things will change.

review_title: Have worked full time at ARMC for 8 years
pros: Athens is a great place to live! Lots of good nurses and doctors at ARMC. Many good places across the street or very close to get food. Location close to many things on broad street.
cons:
Have steadily cut pay, benefits, positions in the last 2 years. Many, many people have been fired this year! Very few units have the same directors since Jamey Thaw CEO came. Some units are on there 2nd director since he came. Prefers to have cheaper ancillary personal and nurses. These are nurses with much much less experience. Prefers part time nurses over full time nurses. ARMC has no part time benefits.
      Insurance for next year has a 4,500 deductible with an 80$ co-pay for a specialist visit. ARMC owns Athens Area Health Plan Select and many, many general practitioner and pediatrician offices. This seems to me to be a conflict of interest.

review_title: Beautiful campus on the outside, with many great employees, but upper management and organization is a nightmare.
pros: Generally nice working environment/working conditions; you get exercise room access for being an employee or volunteer. Most staff members are extremely friendly and helpful, and fun to work with. The company trains during the first week of work on how to be an exceptional employee, which can be helpful beyond working at ARMC.
cons: There is very little room for advancement or even horizontal movement within the company.  Upper management does not seem to care about issues if someone low on the totem pole brings concerns about administrative operations to their attention. The administration is quick to "dismiss" employees under the guise of sudden budget cuts and position eliminations. Extremely unorganized hierarchy of power. Every department is like an entirely different entity as far as internal operations go; very little coherency and communication between departments. Constant changes in leadership, which leads to constant changes and inconsistencies in policies and procedures.

pros: Front line staff for patient care is dedicated.   Strong feeling of community and service to community.    Pay is reasonable.   Benefits are fair but penalties for not using Athens Regional Pharmacy are a slap in face that offset other benfits.
cons:
Extremely weak management at all levels.   Managers fail to manage staff or issues.   Most managers  take an "iron hand / my way or the highway" approach.    Others try to be their staff's best friend and fail to hold them  accountable for anything.   The few good managers are becoming increasingly frustrated.      There is a lot of  "us against them" politics between work groups.    

The Information Services department is too small for the scope of work and project schedules they are asked to support.    The department has survived this long by heroic effort of specific individuals (many of whom have become frustrated and left over the past two years).    Frontline IS staff level has been reduced by 25% over the last few years while additional levels of management (CTO / Director) have been added.   An IS department of this size should not require CIO, CMO, CTO, and mutliple director positions in addition to front line unit managers.  

IS staff roles are changed randomly based on the current crisis; whims of newly arrived management/consultants; or the current manager's inability to address staff performance issues.

review_title: People are leaving for a reason
pros: Currently not many.  The benefits are a positive but they have been dramatically cut over the past 2 years.
cons:
As an employee for more than 10 years, I have seen Athens Regional go from a vibrant and expanding hospital to losing many of its best and brightest employees over the course of only two years.  The hospital is no longer increasing its patient base but rather struggling to function on a day-to-day basis.  The IT department has been decimated by its current CIO.  Her complete lack of communication with her own department as well as the rest of the hospital means that her decisions (and she makes all IT decisions) are made in a vacuum with no basis in real life experience.  Subsequently the people who use tech have absolutely no input into what tech they get to use.  People are really told what they get and to make it work.  This has resulted in extreme inefficiencies and risky patient safety policies.

More importantly, the CEO is completely out of touch with his hospital.  On the one hand he puts out politically correct and glowing e-mails and blog posts about how wonderful the hospital is running.  In reality, his decisions to fire key long term and well respected personnel, completely suppress any opinion other than his own by threat of termination, and spend incredible amounts of hospital money on systems that were poorly chosen, again with no input from the people who will actually use them, have placed the hospital in a financially unstable state.  The hospital board seems oblivious that his actions place the hospital at risk.  There is a fear amongst upper and mid level managers and directors that any dissent or opinion that does not line up with the C-level thought will result in termination.  Subsequently, there is no discussion or evaluation prior to the institution of new policies.  And the fear is real.  Multiple high-level well thought of managers have been terminated without warning and for no apparent reason other than they expressed a dissenting opinion.

As a result of all this, the hospital is struggling.  It will take a new CEO with the ability to utilize the wealth of intellectual treasure that is the hospital's employees for ARMC return to its stature as a vibrant and growing hospital.

pros: Everything good about ARMC has vanished. There are no rewards to working at ARMC besides knowing you took exceptional care of the community while you were at work.
cons: It use to be a teamwork environment. The company cared about its employees at one time, but unfortunately that is no longer the case. You are another replaceable body and they let you know how little you are valued especially when performance appraisal awards are withheld due to the "economy". They expect everything from you including sacrificing your time with family for the good of the company. They don't allow you to be a human being with a real life. Should you be a woman and decide to have children, expect to not have career advancement opportunities and a condescending patriarchal leadership to your new role as a mother. They love to make examples out of pregnant workers and push them to the breaking point and make them go out on maternity leave early. If you can no longer do your job description due to an injury from work, be ready to be kicked to the curb. You are replaceable and they thrive on replacing you with someone younger and cheaper. The good 'ol boy network is still alive and well in this hospital. HR is not your friend. Do not trust HR to have your best interest in mind, because they don't.  You need to listen and read between the words in order to protect yourself. Keep very detailed records of everything that happens and not on ARMC's computers. If you can start your career at ARMC and retire from there with the new management team in place, my hats off to you. Goodluck!
